statesmanjournal.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of the Statesman Journal, a newspaper serving Salem, Oregon, and the surrounding area in Oregon’s Willamette Valley.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

StatesmanJournal.com is owned by Gannett Company Inc., a publicly traded company that owns more than 100 news organizations around the country, including its flagship publication USA Today. Those news sites make up the USA Today Network, which Gannett formed in 2015.

Gannett publications generate revenue through advertisements and subscriptions for their printed publications, websites, and other digital products.

Gannett-owned publications have won numerous awards for their journalism, including three Pulitzer Prizes in 2018.

The Statesman Journal’s revenue comes from advertising and print and digital subscriptions.

Content

Statesmanjournal.com offers a wide range of originally reported local news items, covering politics, sports, crime, real estate/development, agriculture, and the lottery. It also offers national news reported by USA Today, the flagship newspaper of Statesmanjournal.com’s parent company, Gannett.

Credibility

Statesmanjournal.com’s reporting is accurate and well-sourced, with reporting steps outlined where necessary. Headlines are accurate, images are attributed, and opinion content is marked, with a separate page featuring columnists.

Statesmanjournal.com issues corrections when appropriate, including via social media, and has a public corrections policy which invites readers to report errors and outlines the five clear steps reporters and editors take in addressing them. The site also links to a shared USA Today Network ethics policy at the bottom of its homepage.

Transparency

Statesmanjournal.com’s About page contains a detailed history of the Statesman Journal newspaper, as well as lengthy information on its parent company, Gannett. The website’s masthead also makes clear that it is part of the USA Today Network. The site lists names and email addresses for executives, editors, and reporters, albeit without biographies, and also has a generic contact form. Stories have clear bylines and advertisements are very clearly labeled.

History

The Statesman Journal started as two separate newspapers: the Oregon Statesman, which was founded in 1851, and the Capital Journal, founded in 1888. The papers’ business operations merged in 1954 and were taken over by Gannett in 1973. The combined Statesman Journal  first published in 1980.
